Objects are initialized by a value given. When an object is defined for a certain task.
They are initialized with a " . " (dot) between the constructor and the object being created.

objectname classname();

to call a function from the class:

objectname.funciton();
If the object refers to a class, the constructor(s) will initialize the objects based on return type and parameters passed. Compiler will auto-create one if one is not provided.
classname objectname(input parameters);
When the class is called by the Constructor
Constructors; default when not provided by user, or programmer specified constructors.
Objects are usually initialized at the beginning of the program and are initialized usually in the main function. They are initialized after the class's name.
<variable type> <variable name>; or, if you want to initialize a variable to a certain value, <variable type> <variable name> = <value>;
variables are set to a given value, or 0 if none is given.
When the object is initialized, its constructor is called (whether one is provided or c++ assigns a default constructor).
Objects are initialized essentially as copies of the corresponding classes, complete with their own separate variables.

If you had a class Gradebook, you would initialize it in your main function by use of a constructor in the Gradebook class. If no constructor is specified or found, c++ will use a default one with no parameters.

Gradebook myGradebook;

In this bit of code, the class Gradebook has been initialized as object myGradebook.
